question:
If a matrix has $$13$$ elements, then the possible
dimensions (orders) of the matrix are
solution:
If order of matrix $A= a \times b$
Then number of element in $A = ab$

Given $ab=13$

So, $a=1, b=13$

or $b=1, a= 13$

So, $1\times 13$ or $13 \times 1$ are possible order of A.
subject: Maths

question: A matrix has $$16$$ elements Which of the following can be the order of the matrix?
solution:
A matrix of $ m $ rows and $ n $ columns has $ m \times n $ elements.

On multiplying the rows and columns in the given options, we notice that all $ 1 \times 16 = 16, 2 \times 8 = 16, 4 \times 4 = 16 $
subject: Maths

question: If $$A=\displaystyle \left[ \begin{matrix} 1 &2 \\ 3& 4 \end{matrix} \right] $$, then which of the following is not an element of $$A$$?
solution:
$0$ is not present in given matrix.
Option $A$ is correct.
subject: Maths

question: If the order of the matrix is $$1\times2$$, then it is a
solution:
Row Matrix is a matrix with only one row.

The dimension of a row matrix is given as $1 \times n$ where $n$ is the number of columns.
The order of the matrix is given $1\times 2$
So, it has one row and $2$ columns
Therefore, it is a row matrix.
Hence, option A is correct.
subject: Maths

question: If $$A=\begin{bmatrix}1 & 1 &1 \end{bmatrix}$$, then $$A$$ is a
solution:
The given matrix $A=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$, has only one row but multiple columns.
So, $A$ is the row matrix.
subject: Maths

question:
$$\begin{bmatrix}
 2  & 3   \\ 
 3  & 2       
\end{bmatrix}$$ is______________ matrix
solution:
A matrix $A=({A}_{ij})_{m\times n}$ is said to be a square matrix when number of row elements is equal to number of column elements.
So from given matrix, we have $m= 2, n = 2$
Hence, given matrix is a square matrix.
subject: Maths

question: A matrix which is not a square matrix is called a _______ matrix.
solution:
A matrix which is not a square matrix is called a $\text{rectangular}$ matrix.
For example, a rectangular matrix is $A=[a_{ij}]_{m\times n}$, where $m\neq n$
subject: Maths

question: $$\begin{bmatrix}0 &0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}$$ is an example of
solution:
A matrix in which all the elements are equal to $0$ is called zero matrix or null matrix.
$\therefore $ $[ 0 \space 0 \space 0 ]$ is a null matrix.
Option D is correct.
subject: Maths

question: If A and B are square matrices of order 'n' such that $$A^2-B^2=(A-B)(A+B)$$, then which of the following will be true?
solution:
R.H.S. $= (A - B)(A + B) = A(A + B) - B(A + B)$
$= A^2 + AB - BA - B^2$
This will become equal to L.H.S. only when $AB = BA$
subject: Maths

question: A square matrix $$(a_{ij})$$ in which $$a_{ij}=0$$ for $$i \neq j$$ and $$a_{ij}= k (constant)$$ for $$i=j$$ is a
solution:
In the given matrix all the elements other than the diagonal are zero and diagonal elements are equal to K "a "diagonal matrix is a matrix in which the entries outside the main diagonal are all zero "
and "A diagonal matrix with all its main diagonal entries equal is a scalar matrix"
subject: Maths

question: Matrix subtraction is associative
solution:
It is false.
Because,
for matrices $A,B,C$ of same order,
$(A-B)-C\neq A-(B-C)$
$\because A-(B-C)=A-B+C$ and
$(A-B)-c=A-B-C$
So, Matrix subtraction is not associative.
subject: Maths

question:
If $$ A\quad =\quad \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 2 & 4 \end{bmatrix},\quad B\quad =\quad \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 4 & 3 \end{bmatrix}\quad and\quad C\quad =\quad \begin{bmatrix} 4 & 3 \\ 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix} $$ find
$$ (AB) C $$
solution:
$ (AB) $
$ =\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 2 & 4 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 4 & 3 \end{bmatrix} $

$=\begin{bmatrix} 1+12 & 2+9 \\ 2+16 & 4+12 \end{bmatrix} $

$ =\begin{bmatrix} 13 & 11 \\ 18 & 16 \end{bmatrix} $

$ (AB) C $
$ = \begin{bmatrix} 13 & 11 \\ 18 & 16 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 4 & 3 \\ 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 52+11 & 39+22 \\ 72+16 & 54+32 \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 63 & 61 \\ 88 & 86 \end{bmatrix}$
subject: Maths

question: If $$\begin{bmatrix} \alpha  & \beta  \\ \gamma  & -\alpha  \end{bmatrix}$$ is to be the square root of a two -rowed unit matrix, then $$\alpha,\beta$$ and $$\gamma$$ should satisfy the relation.
solution:
We are given a two-rowed unit matrix A, $A=\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{vmatrix}$

Also given a matrix B such that $B=\begin{vmatrix} \alpha & \beta \\ \gamma & -\alpha \end{vmatrix}$ and $\sqrt { A } =B\Rightarrow A={ B }^{ 2 }$
Now ${ B }^{ 2 }=\begin{vmatrix} \alpha & \beta \\ \gamma & -\alpha \end{vmatrix}\begin{vmatrix} \alpha & \beta \\ \gamma & -\alpha \end{vmatrix}=\begin{vmatrix} { \alpha }^{ 2 }+\beta \gamma & 0 \\ 0 & { \alpha }^{ 2 }+\beta \gamma \end{vmatrix}$

$\therefore A={ B }^{ 2 }\Rightarrow \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{vmatrix}=\begin{vmatrix} { \alpha }^{ 2 }+\beta \gamma & 0 \\ 0 & { \alpha }^{ 2 }+\beta \gamma \end{vmatrix}$

Now by law of equality, ${ \alpha }^{ 2 }+\beta \gamma =1\Rightarrow 1-{ \alpha }^{ 2 }-\beta \gamma =0$
subject: Maths

question: Two matrices $$A$$ and $$B$$ are multiplied to get $$BA$$, if
solution: Two matrices $A$ and $B$ are multiplied to get $BA$, if number of rows of $A$ is equal to number of columns of $B$.
subject: Maths

question:
If $$A_\alpha \, = \, \begin{bmatrix}cos \, \, n\alpha & \sin \, n\alpha \\ -\sin \, n\alpha  &\cos \, \,  n\alpha \end{bmatrix}$$ , then the prove following .
$$A_\alpha\,A_\beta \, = \, A_{\alpha + \beta} \, =\,A_\beta A_\alpha $$
solution:
$A_\alpha\,A_\beta \, = \,\begin{bmatrix}cos \, \alpha& sin \,\alpha\\ -sin \, \alpha & cos \, \alpha \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}cos \, \beta& sin \,\beta\\ -sin \, \beta & cos \, \beta \end{bmatrix}$
$= \,\begin{bmatrix}cos \, (\alpha + \beta)& sin \,(\alpha + \beta)\\ -sin \, (\alpha + \beta) & cos \, (\alpha + \beta)\end{bmatrix} \, = \, A_{\alpha + \beta}$
Also $A_\beta \cdot A_\alpha \, = \, A_{\alpha + \beta}$ which can be shown as above . Hence proved .
subject: Maths

question: If $$A$$ and $$B$$ are two square matrices of order $$n$$ and $$A$$ and $$B$$ commute then for any real number $$K$$, then
solution:
$AB = BA$ (GIven)
Consider $(A-KI)(B-KI)$
where, $K$ is any real number
$(A-KI)(B-KI)= AB-K(A+B)+K^{2}$
Interchanging $A$ and $B$, we get
$(B-KI)(A-KI)= BA-K(B+A)+K^{2}$
Since $A,B$ commute with each other
$\therefore (B-KI)(A-KI)= BA-K(B+A)+K^{2} \\\quad\quad= AB - K(A+B) +K^2 = (A-KI)(B-KI)$
Hence, option A is true and option C is false.

We cannot say anything about equality of $A-KI$ and $B-KI$, since it is not given that $A$ and $B$ are equal or not.
Hence, option B is false.

Consider $(A+KI)(B-KI)$
$(A+KI)(B-KI) = AB - K(A-B) - K^2$
Since $A,B$ commute with each other,
$\therefore (B-KI)(A+KI)= BA-K(B+A)+K^{2} = AB + K(A-B) +K^2 \neq (A+KI)(B-KI)$
It is proved that, $A+KI, B-KI$ do not commute with each other.
Hence, option D is false.
subject: Maths

question: If $$A$$ and $$B$$ are two matrices such that $$AB = B$$ and $$BA = A$$, then $$A^2+B^2$$ equals
solution:
Given,
$AB = B$
and
$BA=A$
Now,
$A^2+B^2=A\cdot A+B\cdot B$
$=A(BA)+B(AB)=(AB)A+(BA)B$
$=BA+AB=A+B$
subject: Maths

question: If A is a square matrix of order 3,then $$|Adj\left( Adj{ A }^{ 2 } \right) |=$$
subject: Maths

question:
The multiplication of matrices is distributive with respect to the matrix addition.
State true or false.
solution: It is well known fact that, Multiplication of matrices is distributive with respect to the matrix addition. i.e $ A(B+C)=AB+AC$
subject: Maths

question: The transpose of a rectangular matrix is a
solution:
If we exchange the role of the row and column of a matrix then we transpose it.This operation is called transposition and the matrix is called transposition matrix.
If we take a rectangular matrix and transpose it then we get a rectangular matrix.
subject: Maths

question: $$(A+AB)^{T}=XA^{T}$$,  $$\mathrm{X}=$$
solution:
From equation
$\Rightarrow \left ( A+AB \right )^{T}$
$\Rightarrow A^{T}+B^{T}A^{T} $ $\left \{ We \quad known \quad that \left ( AB \right )^{T}=B^{T}A^{T} \right \}$
$\Rightarrow A^{T}\left ( I+B^{T} \right )$
$\Rightarrow A^{T}X$
$\therefore$ $ X= I$ $+$ $B^{T}$
subject: Maths

question: Which of the following is not true, if $$\mathrm{A}$$and $$\mathrm{B}$$ are two matrices each of order $$n\times n$$, then
solution:
By property of transpose of any matrix
$\left ( A+B \right )^{T}=A^{T}+B^{T}=B^{T}+A^{T}$
$\left ( A-B \right )^{T}=A^{T}-B^{T}$
$\left ( AB\right )^{T}=B^{T}A^{T}$
$\left ( A B C \right )^{T}= C^{T} B^{T} A^{T}$
subject: Maths

question: If $$A$$ is skew-symmetric matrix and $$n$$ is odd positive integer, then $$A^n$$ is
solution:
For a skew-symmetric matrix A, $A^T=-A.$
$(A^n)^T= (-1)^nA^n$, since n is an odd integer then $A^n$ is also a skew-symmetric matrix.
subject: Maths

question:
Which of the following is the new row that results when you add rows $$1$$ and $$3$$?
$$\begin{bmatrix}3&4&2&11\\9&1&0&0\\0&1&0&2\\0&0&6&1\end{bmatrix}$$
solution:
Given Matrix$=\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 4 & 2 & 11 \\ 9 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 & 2 \\ 0 & 0 & 6 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$
Row $1=\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 4 & 2 & 11 \end{bmatrix}$
Row $3=\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix}$
Sum$=\begin{bmatrix} 3+0 & 4+1 & 2+0 & 11+2 \end{bmatrix}$
$\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 5 & 2 & 13 \end{bmatrix}$
$\therefore $Option $2$ is correct
subject: Maths

question:
The value of $$\left|\begin{array}{ll}
2+i & 2-i\\
1+i & 1-i
\end{array}\right|$$ is:
solution:
Let $A=\begin{vmatrix}
2+i & 2-i\\
1+i & 1-i
\end{vmatrix}$
$det A=(2+i)(1-i)-(2-i)(1+i)$
$=2-i+1-[2+i+1]$
$=-2i$
$\Rightarrow det A= -2i\Rightarrow A $ complex quantity.
subject: Maths

question: A determinant of second order is made with the elements 0 and 1. Find the number of determinants with non-negative values.
solution:
In required determinant , each of the four elements can be filled in $2$ ways i.e. by $0$ or $1$.
So, possible number of determinants $= 2^4=16$
subject: Maths

question: If A is a square matrix of order n such that its elements are polynomials in x and its r-rows become identical for   $$x = \alpha $$  then
solution:
Since $x-a$ will be common factor from each of r-rows which vanish by putting $x=\alpha $,

Therefore ${ \left( x-\alpha \right) }^{ r-1 }$ will be factor of $|A|$
subject: Maths
